index.title: Welcome to Election Watch
index.manifest:
We live troubled times. Technology advances at a faster pace than that which society can accommodate, and that has consequences, good and bad. The good ones are irreplaceable, yet the bad are terrifying. Social Networks represent an ocean of information, where lie dissolves in truth, where anyone can dump a bucket of what they think is truth, or whatever they feel. This project is a small effort to separate the waters, of showing and acknowledging there the truth is in danger, just like justice, the planet, democracies and, in extremis, all of our lives and ways of living. The goal of this project is to give a more analytical and transparent look upon the reality of social networks in Portugal. In particular, to the Portuguese Presidential Elections of January 2021.
Election Watch is a child project of Twitter Watch, a tool for data collection developed in the context of my MSc thesis at the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Porto. The source code is open-source and any citizen can make suggestions or report bugs.
index.footer: At the moment, we are only monitoring Twitter, but we plan to further extend our analyses and also expand them to other social networks.

tweet_types.title: Analysis of the different tweet types
tweet_types.explanation:
The two plots below show the daily evolution of the four types of tweets possible:
  • originals : text produced directly by the account
  • retweets : original tweet shared by another user
  • quotes : retweet with novel content added
  • reply : a direct reply to a tweet, typical show in a reply thread below the tweet

It is important to highlight that the number of watched accounts can vary and, with them, the number of daily tweets can also vary. However, this can be cross-checked with the values in our DB Stats page.

creation_dates.title: Year and month of account creation
creation_dates.explanation: The creation date of accounts is one of the main factors that raise suspicions of malicious intent. The peak of account creation registered between March and April 2020 is naturally a consequence of the Covid-19 pandemic and the isolation measures taken in Portugal. This phenomenon was also described in the MSc Thesis that supports the creation of Election Watch.

similarity.title: Analysis of the similarity of followeres among the different candidates
similarity.description: This table shows the Jaccard Index (JI) for the followers of each pair of candidates. Higher values mean a greater similarity between the two follower sets. If two candidates have exactly the same number of followers, the JI value will be 1. This is one possible metric of polarization between followers. It is expected that candidates that appeal to the same users share a larger JI value.
similarity.plot_title: Similarity between sets of followers (Jaccard Index)

intersection.title: Analysis of followers intersection
intersection.description: On the other hand, this table allows us to answer the question: What percentage of followers of a candidate also follows another. In this case, what percentage of followers of the candidate on a given row, follow the candidate on a given column. Naturally, the main diagonal is excluded as this value is always 1, since every candidate shares all followers with her/himself :)
intersection.plot_title: Percentage of followers of Candidate-row that follow Candidate-column

radar.title: Analysis of follower intersection
radar.description: In this plot, we can see the same information as in the previous table in a new way, which highlights the differences in how each candidate can appeal to the followers of other candidates.
